moves.1... c5 2. Bc4 e5 3. Qf3: I know this isn't the wisest course of action.  I was more or less making sure he was paying attention.
moves.3... Qf6: An interesting reply.  Now the ladies take center stage...
moves.4. d3 d6 5. Nc3 Nc6 6. Nd5: Now he's in a pickle.  He has to take my Q or move his very carefully.
moves.6... Qxf3 7. Nxf3: Elizabeth has left the building, now off to partake in my nasty scheme.
moves.7... Kd7: Ahh...black does not fail to forget my royal steed and the upcoming fork.
moves.8. Ng5 Nh6 9. O-O f6: Now, it's here that I see supreme infiltration.
moves.10. f4: If he takes pxN then my pxp leaving my R the open F-file. :)   Not to mention my pawn will be attacking his N so he'll have to move him swiftly and give my Rook the f7 square for check.  This take is what I named the game after, to take or not to take.  Look a gift horse in the mouth?
moves.12. Rf7+: Note he can't move to e6, because N-c7 is #
he resigns here, his Knight is toast no matter where he moves.  he would be -6 after the N moves and I take.

gameName: To Take or Not to Take
